bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical Information
bioghist.p: Ann Maria Sturtevant and Owen Sturtevant were married and lived in Maquon, Knox County, Illinois. other family members lived in Springfield and Monticello, Illinois.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Information
scopecontent.p: There are 145 pages worth of letters in this collection ranging from 1858-1884. Most of the letters include information about family births and deaths, illnesses and daily happenings. The pre-Civil War era letters are mostly information on family and farm affairs. The letters that were written during the Civil War contain information on family affairs,information on the members of the Sturtevant family in the Union army, and local happenings. The post-civil war letters cover family affairs including the divorce of Ann Sturtevant's brother William.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Sturtevant letters are arranged in alphabetical order according to the author of the letter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Information
scopecontent.p: Letter to Sister Ann from Elizabeth Durkee dated September 23, 1864, mentions an uncle selling one negro and future plans to sell nine.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Information
scopecontent.p: Letter written December 8, 1860 mentioning finding eleven negroes and searching records for others. Also inquires whether the recipient, "Sir", thinks Montgomery and Durkee should go to Maryland for further searching.
